CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: We want to use an online grammar checking tool, which takes each word from the client and sends it to the web server. The available network bandwidth between the client and the server is 2 Gbps. What should be the maximum allowed size(in MBs) of a document containing the word sent from the client to the server per second for the grammar check? (Use: 1KB= 1000Bytes, 1MB=1000KB and so on.)
question_texts: We want to use an online grammar checking tool, which takes each word from the client and sends it to the web server. The available network bandwidth between the client and the server is 2 Gbps. What should be the maximum allowed size(in MBs) of a document containing the word sent from the client to the server per second for the grammar check? (Use: 1KB= 1000Bytes, 1MB=1000KB and so on.)

questions.question_text_1: Consider a client which is located 3000 km from the server makes a request through the cable. Suddenly after the request reaches the server, the cable breaks and the response is now to be sent to the client via air. This change of medium caused an additional delay of 47 ms at the server end. How long will the client have to wait before receiving the response (in ms)? ( speed on cable = 2e8 m/s and in air 3e8 m/s)
question_texts: Consider a client which is located 3000 km from the server makes a request through the cable. Suddenly after the request reaches the server, the cable breaks and the response is now to be sent to the client via air. This change of medium caused an additional delay of 47 ms at the server end. How long will the client have to wait before receiving the response (in ms)? ( speed on cable = 2e8 m/s and in air 3e8 m/s)

props.summary: ### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations #### 1. **HTML and CSS** - **HTML Structure**: Understanding the basic structure of HTML documents, including tags like ``, ``, ``, ``, and `<p>`. - **HTML Lists**: Knowledge of different types of lists in HTML, such as definition lists (`<dl>`), and their respective tags (`<dt>`, `<dd>`). - **CSS Selectors**: Understanding how CSS selectors work, including class selectors (`.class`), ID selectors (`#id`), and descendant selectors. - **CSS Specificity**: Knowledge of how CSS specificity determines which styles are applied to an element. #### 2. **Flask and Jinja2** - **Flask Routes**: Understanding how to define routes in Flask using the `@app.route` decorator. - **Jinja2 Templates**: Knowledge of how to use Jinja2 templates to render dynamic content in Flask. - **Template Rendering**: Understanding how to render templates in Flask using `render_template` and `render_template_string`. - **Macros in Jinja2**: Knowledge of how to define and use macros in Jinja2 templates. - **URL Handling**: Understanding how to handle URLs and redirects in Flask using `url_for` and `redirect`. #### 3. **Python Programming** - **Command Line Arguments**: Understanding how to handle command line arguments in Python using `sys.argv`. - **String Manipulation**: Knowledge of string manipulation functions like `join`, `split`, and formatting. - **Error Handling**: Understanding common errors like key errors and how to handle them. #### 4. **Networking and Data Transfer** - **Bandwidth and Data Transfer**: Understanding how to calculate the maximum allowed size of data transfer based on bandwidth. - **Network Latency**: Knowledge of how to calculate network latency based on distance and medium (cable vs. air). #### 5. **Mathematical Calculations** - **Unit Conversion**: Understanding how to convert units, such as pounds to kilograms. - **Protein Intake Calculation**: Knowledge of how to calculate recommended daily protein intake based on gender and weight. ### Equations #### Network Bandwidth Calculation - **Bandwidth (B)**: Given as 2 Gbps. - **Data Size (S)**: To be calculated in MBs. - **Time (T)**: 1 second. The relationship between bandwidth, data size, and time is given by: \[ B = \frac{S}{T} \] Given \( B = 2 \text{ Gbps} = 2 \times 10^9 \text{ bits per second} \) and \( T = 1 \text{ second} \), we can calculate the data size \( S \) in bits: \[ S = B \times T = 2 \times 10^9 \text{ bits} \] To convert bits to megabytes (MB), we use the conversion factors: \[ 1 \text{ byte} = 8 \text{ bits} \] \[ 1 \text{ KB} = 1000 \text{ bytes} \] \[ 1 \text{ MB} = 1000 \text{ KB} \] So, \[ S \text{ (in MB)} = \frac{2 \times 10^9 \text{ bits}}{8 \times 10^6 \text{ bits/MB}} = 250 \text{ MB} \] #### Network Latency Calculation - **Distance (D)**: 3000 km. - **Speed in Cable (V_c)**: \( 2 \times 10^8 \text{ m/s} \). - **Speed in Air (V_a)**: \( 3 \times 10^8 \text{ m/s} \). - **Additional Delay (T_d)**: 47 ms. The time taken for the signal to travel through the cable is: \[ T_c = \frac{D}{V_c} \] The time taken for the signal to travel through the air is: \[ T_a = \frac{D}{V_a} \] The total delay is the sum of the time taken to travel through the cable and the additional delay: \[ T_{total} = T_c + T_d \] Substituting the values: \[ T_c = \frac{3000 \times 10^3 \text{ m}}{2 \times 10^8 \text{ m/s}} = 15 \text{ ms} \] \[ T_{total} = 15 \text{ ms} + 47 \text{ ms} = 62 \text{ ms} \] However, the correct answer provided is 72 ms, which suggests there might be additional considerations or a different interpretation of the problem. ### Mermaid Knowledge Graph ```mermaid graph TD; A[HTML and CSS] --> B[HTML Structure] A --> C[HTML Lists] A --> D[CSS Selectors] A --> E[CSS Specificity] F[Flask and Jinja2] --> G[Flask Routes] F --> H[Jinja2 Templates] F --> I[Template Rendering] F --> J[Macros in Jinja2] F --> K[URL Handling] L[Python Programming] --> M[Command Line Arguments] L --> N[String Manipulation] L --> O[Error Handling] P[Networking and Data Transfer] --> Q[Bandwidth and Data Transfer] P --> R[Network Latency] S[Mathematical Calculations] --> T[Unit Conversion] S --> U[Protein Intake Calculation] ``` ```mermaid graph TD; B[HTML Structure] --> B1[Tags: html, head, body, title, p] C[HTML Lists] --> C1[Definition Lists: dl, dt, dd] D[CSS Selectors] --> D1[Class Selectors: .class] D --> D2[ID Selectors: #id] D --> D3[Descendant Selectors] E[CSS Specificity] --> E1[Specificity Rules] G[Flask Routes] --> G1[@app.route Decorator] H[Jinja2 Templates] --> H1[Dynamic Content Rendering] I[Template Rendering] --> I1[render_template] I --> I2[render_template_string] J[Macros in Jinja2] --> J1[Macro Definition and Usage] K[URL Handling] --> K1[url_for] K --> K2[redirect] M[Command Line Arguments] --> M1[sys.argv] N[String Manipulation] --> N1[join, split, formatting] O[Error Handling] --> O1[Key Errors] Q[Bandwidth and Data Transfer] --> Q1[Bandwidth Calculation] R[Network Latency] --> R1[Latency Calculation] T[Unit Conversion] --> T1[Pounds to Kilograms] U[Protein Intake Calculation] --> U1[Gender and Weight Based Calculation] ``` This summary and knowledge graph should help you understand the core topics, concepts, principles, and equations essential for the exam.
